title: Simple harmonic motion - calc position from accel

content.question: One end of a horizontal spring with spring constant <math alttext="100 newtons per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></math> is attached to a block of mass <math alttext="0.50 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>, and the other end is attached to a wall. The block can slide with negligible friction along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis on a horizontal surface. When the block is at position <math alttext="x equals 0.75 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, the spring is at its unstretched length. From which of the following positions can the block be released and have a maximum acceleration with magnitude <math alttext="20 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>m/s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="0.10 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.20 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.65 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.95 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.95</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="0.65 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
